but in the end life is too short not to

it's you know you it's all about being
people together and if we disagreed on

probably regret it but do I think

probably not have you heard from them
not all but you would be prepared to

what do you think they meant by

IVF has brought so much pleasure and and

and they're all wonderful little things

I've two children over four and two and

they're just beautiful and and no child

testified before the US Congress I think
it was 13 years ago how much progress
have you seen in the fight against AIDS
since then well it's enormous progress
that's been made
I mean 13 years ago there wasn't PEPFAR
there wasn't a Global Fund I mean we
were in a really bad way and a lot has
changed thanks to the leadership of
America and to Britain as well and to
other countries around the world but the
Americans have given 33% up to the

PEPFAR and that really changed the whole

when you testify today before the US
Senate you talked about a moment of risk
yeah that we are in a moment in time
where things could start spiraling out
of control again the biggest second
biggest cause of death in the world
amongst young juvenile women is AIDS
that's astounding that's terrifying
so we have so much more work to do and
I'm here today just to say to the
government thank you so much keep your
foot on the accelerator and to the
British government as well and to the
countries in the EU and other countries
that don't give us much like China and
Thailand and Japan to say come to the
party come to the party because this is
a global epidemic and if we come to the

can make so much more progress we've
made a lot of progress but there's still
a lot of work to be done is there a risk

the progress and you outlined it to the

don't even talk about AIDS not even
aware of it because AIDS is treatable
it's like it's more treatable and
diabetes if you have the antiretroviral
drugs you can live a long and healthy
life
I mean 13 years ago people I knew was
selling their insurance and their homes
because they thought they were gonna die
and then suddenly they were back in the

so I do think there is a complacency
with in the Western world anyway to say

so we don't have to bother which is

yeah Indiana a spike in infections again
well that's been going on because
they've got you know there was a
national needle exchange program that
was put in place and then it was taken
out so you've got places now like in

related drug intravenous drug use but
it's it's you know it's likely become
kind of a little epidemic and it's made

in a there's no common sense involved
it's like it's common sense to have a
needle exchange program you have said
before the Senate that you think you
could see the end of AIDS in your

really if I didn't believe it I wouldn't
be sitting here today and I wouldn't be
here
canvassing the Senate and the Congress
and the American
what's it gonna take it's gonna take a

yes we have to cut before the

this is one percent of the budget it's
nothing
do you think America is gonna do the

it wasn't a Democrat it was a Republican
